trial_identification.studytitle: Nambour Community-based Skin Cancer Prevention Trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Community-based trial of daily versus usual sunscreen use and beta-carotene versus placebo supplements to prevent skin cancer

conditions.healthcondition: squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
blood lipids as assessed by fasting blood tests

interventions.interventions:
"Daily sunscreen, Beta-carotene supplements" Daily sunscreen: (Sun Protection Factor (SPF) 15+, to be applied to head, neck, arms and hands every morning (and to reapply after heavy sweating, bathing, or long sun exposure), for 5 years.
Beta-carotene supplements: 30mg once daily as oral capsule, for 5 years.
4 arms in trial viz. Arm 1: daily sunscreen, beta-carotene supplements Arm 2: daily sunscreen, placebo supplements Arm 3: beta-carotene supplements, discretionary sunscreen Arm 4: discretionary sunscreen, placebo supplements
interventions.comparator: "discretionary sunscreen, placebo supplements" Discretionary sunscreen for 5 years. Placebo: microcellulose pills, once daily, orally, for 5 years

primaryOutcome.outcome: basal cell carcinoma (BCC) incidence: ascertained by clinical examination and medical records; histologically-confirmed
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 5 years after randomisation; 8 years after cessation of trial (or 13 years after randomisation)

primaryOutcome.outcome: squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) incidence: ascertained by clinical examination and medical records; histologically-confirmed
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 5 years after randomisation; 8 years after cessation of trial (or 13 years after randomisation)

primaryOutcome.outcome: solar keratosis (SK) prevalence: SK clinically diagnosed by dermatologists
photogeing severity: assessed clinically and by microtopography using silicon casts of the back of the hand
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 5 years after randomisation; 10 years after cessation of trial (or 15 years after randomisation)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: melanoma incidence: melanomas ascertained through medical records and cancer registry; histologically-confirmed and reviewed
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 10 years after cessation of trial (or 15 years after randomisation)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: blood lipids as assessed fasting blood test
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at baseline for a random sample and at 5 years (end of trial) for majority of trial participants

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Registered on the state electoral roll for Nambour in Nov 1986

trial_design.concealment: Enrolled by acceptance of letter of invitation. Allocation by central randomisation by computer
trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a randomization table created by a computer software

ethicsAndSummary.summary: A randomised trial was conducted to assess whether daily application of a sun protection factor (SPF) 15+ sunscreen to the head, neck, arms and hands, or beta-carotene supplementation (30 mg/day) would prevent skin cancers and related tumours and premature skin ageing in comparison with discretionary use of sunscreen or a daily placebo supplement. The The hypothesis was that regular sunscreen use by adult Caucasians prevents the occurrence of skin cancers and related sun-related degenerative skin conditions
